ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Also included additional meetings with other professors about further exploring course topics (this were recorded and could be viewed asynchronously)
A twice a week synchronous, virtual seminar along with some optional, some not optional workshops on Fridays to introduce us to some multimedia formats, including podcasts and story maps.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to study an author's body of work and interrogate how his ideas might have shifted. This course gave me the opportunity to consider historical factors and the influence of time on a body of writing. It also allowed me to analyze the relationship between Baldwin's fiction and essays. This was a very engaging and thought-provoking course and provided ample opportunity to think critically and receive feedback about my ideas. I also learned how to use Yale's archives successfully and how to make a podcast, giving me skills that will help me be a more successful english major in the future.
I gained a really in-depth knowledge about James Baldwin's writings. This course explored his fiction, his non-fiction, and his surrounding cultural impact.

The most valuable insight was that generated through our class discussions. During such a strange and disorienting semester, the course was an anchor to do critical thinking with a cohort of equally passionate students. We not only read Baldwin, we read Baldwin, talked about him with each other, and after amounting knowledge about him and his writing, tried to understand him, the history he lived, and the racial injustice he witnessed. Our discussion revolved around connecting Baldwin's works together, parsing through his writing in context with his lived circumstances, comparing his fiction and non-fiction, and often applying his insight to our modern lives. Prof. Goldsby allowed us to think together and by ourselves, and the projects assigned to us (a mid-term paper and a longer final paper with the option of doing a podcast or story map) only helped us further extend the practices we developed in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths-
-engaging in many different ways 
-varied class format (sometimes breakout rooms, sometimes student-led discussion, use of zoom chat, class visitors, etc. kept me engaged the whole semester)
-varied assignments (essays, canvas posts, podcast, reception archive--all kept me engaged and encouraged me to think critically)
-twice a week meetings (two hour seminars are not fun on Zoom)
-a very understanding and attentive professor (by far the largest strength and life force of this course)
-flexible course schedule that Professor Goldsby adjusted to our needs 

weaknesses
I think it might have been helpful to have guidance on what we should look for / pay attention to in the secondary scholarship we read about Baldwin's texts.
This course was extremely well done. The professor was so involved and excited by the course material, and that made all of the students even more excited about the syllabus as well.

If James Baldwin's works weren't already important enough and genuinely interesting to read, Prof. Goldsby managed to structure the readings in such a way that truly allowed us to form a mental image of the man and a map of his works. Prof. Goldsby was also the highlight of the semester -- she is so knowledgeable, genuinely cares about our growth during the course, and as a result, made class such a joy to be in. The option to explore some other multimedia formats greatly helped during a semester of online courses, where typing so many papers on a laptop we already spend so much time staring at can only get more and more stale. There really are no weaknesses to this course - take this class!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Succeeded-
-varied class format and assignments kept me continually engaged
-flexibility with Zoom (camera optional was very nice at the end of a long zoom class day, though nearly everyone always had their camera on at all times because the course was so engaging)
-ample and accessible zoom office hours

Honestly, this seminar was the best Zoom class I had this semester. I have no suggestions for how to make it better.
I think that this course did an excellent job in spite of the circumstances- this class was able to use the digital format to its advantage at some points as well.

Though discussion seminars generally take a hit from the virtual format, this course remained incredibly engaging -- and I think this was due to Prof. Goldsby's ability to facilitate discussion and detect general sentiment from the students in the class. Rather than concrete practices, I think the most essential part of making any seminar work, and especially a virtual seminar during a pandemic, is being able to sympathize and work together -- professor and students -- and this course definitely accomplished that.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Professor Goldsby led an engaging and thought-provoking class throughout the entirety of an online semester. The coursework helped me learn how to engage with a body of an author's work and think critically about the relationship between literature and history and culture. It also taught me how to do archive research and make a podcast. I feel like I learned so much about James Baldwin and the role of literature in our society. By far, a phenomenal course, even in a novel semester.

Yes- definitely! If you are at all curious about James Baldwin's writings (or if you have never read him at all) then this is the class for you. His writing is really timely and so wonderful, and this class is a really great way to engage with just one author.

One hundred times yes - the readings are incredible, Prof. Goldsby is a joy to learn from and think together with, and she approaches such a seemingly daunting author with an infectious passion and curiosity that makes us all want to work and contribute.
